dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara alone on a bench. She is high above the city, the view is magnificent. She watches the couples, kids playing, families.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: People have always trusted me with their secrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara writing her diary in her one bedroom, basement fl

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But who do I trust with mine? A whole shelf of hardback notebooks, her collection of diaries dating back to the 1950’s.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You. Only you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roar of traffic. The urban ravine of the Archway Road The red, black and gold cast-iron ‘suicide bridge’ which straddles it. Barbara driving to work in her old W Polo. EXT. ST GEORGE’S SCHOOL/CAR PARK —- MORNING The school is a bleak, Victorian building with various mo add-ons. Barbara locks her car and heads for the main entrance. INT. CLASSROOM —- MINUTES LATER Barbara takes out her lesson planner, text books, registr She organizes them neatly on her desk. Barbara stares at the rows of empty desks and chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first day of a new term. Sound of PUPILS arriving outside. Barbara observes them f her high window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids in school uniform stream through the gates.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Here come the local pubescent proles. They play football, gossip, fight and skirmish. A diverse ethnic mix, about fifty percent white.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The future shop assistants and plumbers. And doubtless the odd terrorist too. A teacher (BRIAN) oversees the general activity. SHEBA HART comes in through the main gates pushing her ta old bicycle. She looks a little lost. Brian directs her to the bike racks.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. RECEPTION AREA/MAIN COURTYARD
dialogues.text: Barbara watches TED MAWSON (Deputy Head) outside with She he’s introducing her to MEMBERS OF STAFF passing by.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: In the old days we confiscated cigarettes and ‘wank mags’. Now it’s knives and crack cocaine. And they call it progress. The school bell rings and Sheba is whisked away in anothe direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara writes ‘Wittenberg’ on the board. Other stray phr already there: ‘Diet of worms’ ‘Martin Luther’. She’s teaching ‘The Reformation’ to a class of bored 16 y olds. The bell rings. The kids immediately snatch up their hook leave. Barbara makes a gesture - they sit back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Fuckin’ poison granny. Barbara surveys her class. Another gesture: ‘you may go’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A committee meeting of around TWENTY TEACHERS chaired by Headmaster, SANDY PABBLEM. His secretary (GITA) takes notes. The staff sit in chairs a circle, Barbara amongst them. In passing we see teacher ELAINE CLIFFORD and SUE HODGE.

dialogues.speaker: PABBLEM
dialogues.text: Before we start, can those of you who haven’t delivered your reports please lob ‘em in my general direction. He goes round the circle. Staff hand him their school iss report files, all thick with their work.

dialogues.speaker: PABBLEM
dialogues.text: Thanks Bill, Elaine. Thank you, Linda - how’s Greg?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: A bit better, thanks. He holds his hands together - a gesture of emotional solidarity.

dialogues.speaker: PABBLEM
dialogues.text: Good, good. Sheba comes in mouthing apologies for her lateness.

dialogues.speaker: PABBLEM
dialogues.text: Ah! Has everyone met our new Art teacher, Sheba Hart? General murmars of ‘hello’ and ‘welcome’.

dialogues.speaker: PABBLEM
dialogues.text: I’ve invited Sheba to sit in on this meeting. As you know, I regard The Arts as absolutely central to our policy of ‘reform through nurture.’ Barbara gestures to the empty chair beside her. But anot teacher (BILL RUMER) is comically commanding Sheba to sit next to him. Which she does.

dialogues.speaker: PABBLEM
dialogues.text: Welcome to you. Sheba takes out a note-pad and pen, looking nervous but k Pabblem continues collecting the reports.

dialogues.speaker: PABBLEM
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sue. Ooh, that’s a big one! I’1ll be up ‘til the crack of dawn. Anyone else not handed in their homework? He turns to Barbara, a hint of nervousness.

dialogues.speaker: PABBLEM
dialogues.text: Barbara...? Barbara coolly produces her file. It’s impossibly thin. Pabblem pretends to weigh it on his hand go that others c witness its paucity. Encouraged by polite laughter he opens it to reveal a sin sheet of typed paper.

dialogues.speaker: PABBLEM
dialogues.text: This is your report? On the History Department? On its entire workings? And your general thoughts for its future development?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You’ll find it’s quite thorough, Headmaster. The teachers look tense but one or two are secretly amuse this is vintage Barbara. Gita looks appalled. Pabblem stares at the report; it’s one paragraph long.

dialogues.speaker: PABBLEM
dialogues.text: (reads aloud) ‘The History Department functions much as one would expect for a school of this stature and intake. Examination results have been consistent for thirty years; below the national average but above the level of catastrophe. Recommendation: no change necessary’. Barbara looks innocent, defying Pabblem to explode-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It took me most of the summer to write it. He stares at her in impotent fury. Barbara sneaks a look at Sheba.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hard to read the wispy novice. Is she a sphinx or simply stupid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheba on playground duty, wrapped in a coat, she’s patrol amongst the children. Barbara lurks nearby.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Artfully dishevelled today. The tweedy tramp coat is an abhorrence. It seems to say, ‘I’m just like you’. But clearly she is not. Sheba intervenes between two kids sparring for a fight.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A fey person, I suspect. Fey. suddenly - a roar from some BOYS playing football. The go scorer, a BOY of fifteen, celebrates by whipping his shir off and waving it in jubilation - naked from the waist up

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Put your shirt on!

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: I got the winner, Miss!

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Glory be. Shirt. Barbara glances at Sheba. She seems to be looking straigh her. Barbara wonders if Sheba disapproves her ticking off boy. As he runs away:

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Good goal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara with her tray cating lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has certainly rippled the waters of our stagnant pond. They flock to her. She watches Brian approaching Sheba.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Even limp, little Brian had a go. Oh, the ‘ horror. Other TEACHERS, almost queuing for Sheba’s attention. :

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And Fatty Hodge has pounced on her. Barbara at a grubby canteen table - watching with a seemi benign smile. Sheba and SUE HODGE are on a bench outside, bathed in sunlight as they eat their sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A dubious double-act; the blonde and the pig in knickers. Sue chews like a rabbit as Sheba chortles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara on a break. A few other TEACHERS dotted around. B comes in looking a little sheepish.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: I just went past the Art Studio... Barbara glances up- BRIAN . It’s bloody Lord of the Flies in there.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: Have they gone for her?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: (nods) Torn her posters down, full on paint fight, they're chanting, ‘get your tits out for the lads’. Girls too. It’s carnage.  Barbara looks concerned, shares a shake of the head with Elaine. Bill looks up from the coffee station.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: How was Madam?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Totally lost it. (imitates Sheba) ‘Stop it! Stop it you little fucking bastards.’

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: You should’ve stepped in. Brian looks anxious, thinks she’s right.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: He didn’t want to patronize the little lady. She’1l be alright. The bourgeoisie need a good pasting now and then, reminds ‘em where the true power resides. He lobs a tea-bag in his mug.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: This time next year she’ll be Headmistress. Antonia - another teacher - explodes:

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: Oh Christ, will you shut up?! I’m trying to work! She gestures to a mountain of school books she’s marking.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Sorry, sorry. Char, anyone? (pointedly) Babs?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Milk, no sugar.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Sweet enough?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Evidently.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Didn't her father invent inflation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You what?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Wasn’t her dad that academic; Donald whatsit? Economics bloke, he invented the word ‘inflation’.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: (lying) Oh yeah, yeah, I know who you mean.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: I think you’ll find that Mrs Hart’s father was Professor Ronald Taylor. He didn’t ‘invent inflation’, he devised a theory about the relationship between inflation and consumer expectation. A silence. Brian and Elaine share a look at Barbara’s expense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The school day over. Barbara walks through the lobby. she hears loud noises from the library and goes to look. A photocopied sign on the door: HOMEWORK CLUB. Through the window she sees TWO BOYS fighting and Sheba desperately trying to separate them. OTHER KIDS encourage fighters. It’s mayhem.

dialogues.speaker: SHEBA
dialogues.text: Stop this immediately! Stop it both of you or you’1l be up before the Head! Barbara waits: let Sheba suffer or be her saviour? The chaos continues - she takes a deep breath then bursts bellowing: Int. LIBRARY - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: ENOUGH
dialogues.text: Immediate silence. She parts the boys with swift and vigo force. Sheba is hugely relieved but Barbara’s not finishe yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To the boys) Outside. Now! The two boys file out. Barbara surveys the rest of the cl A BOY has a baseball cap on. Barbara points to her head, boy removes the cap from his own.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (To other kids) Get on with your work! Which they do, at once. And then Barbara marches out. Sheba is unsure whether she’s supposed to follow. Barbara gestures for her to come with. INT. CORRIDOR OUTSIDE LIBRARY — MOMENTS LATER The boys are looking at the floor, hands in pockets.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Why were they fighting, Mrs Hart?

dialogues.speaker: SHEBA
dialogues.text: The motive was unclear.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (To first boy) Davis I know - you’re a little thug, aren’t you? (To second boy) And who might you be? The second boy is STEVEN CONNOLLY (15).

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (mumbling) Steven Connolly, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Steven Connolly, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Year?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Year Ten, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly remembers ) The naked footballer. Why were you fighting? (beat) It’s a perfectly simple question.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Dunno, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You don’t know. One minute you’re an inert lump, the next you’re attempting to castrate a fellow pupil. Nothing cccurred between these two states?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (cod Irish accent) Don’t be a hero, Connolly, it’s hardly da place. (pause) Yes? Brain - mouth - and speak.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) He was saying stuff about Miss. (nods at Sheba) He was bang out of order. This is news to Sheba.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (To Davis) What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: I never said nothing-

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (correcting him) ‘I didn’t say anything’. (To Connolly) What did he say? Oh, come on!

dialogues.speaker: CONNOLLY
dialogues.text: He said she’s a tart...he said he gave her one up the arse. Sheba is shocked, Barbara is not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Davis) Did you indeed? Odious boy, apologize at once.

dialogues.speaker: DAVIS
dialogues.text: (To Sheba) Sorry, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Deputy Head in the morning. Now back in, both of you. The boys shuffle in to the library. Sheba shakes her head

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Little towers of testosterone, you'll get used to them.

dialogues.speaker: SHEBA
dialogues.text: Thank you so much. I’d better... She gestures to the library but Barbara holds out her han

dialogues.speaker: SHEBA
dialogues.text: oh, sorry, we haven’t met properly, have we? Sheba Hart. Art department. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Barbara Covett. History. Barbara watches Sheba go back in. And smiles for the firs time.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Quite a nice voice, plummy and deep. As if her mouth was pure, as if she’d never had a filling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara and Sheba on playground duty. They smile at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0-)
dialogues.text: The complexion of a white peach. One can almost see her veins.  INT. SCHOOL CANTEEN — ANOTHER DAY

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Her trendy politics are similarly transparent . Barbara, Sheba and Sue in the busy lunch queue.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: We serve them best if we teach them to read, write and add. They don’t need to know about the basket weavers of Chile.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Barbara’s very keen on the basics. Sheba helps herself to some sad looking coleslaw.

dialogues.speaker: SHEBA
dialogues.text: (To Barbara) But when you started, didn’t you want to give them a...a real education? To help them overcome - well... (sotto) -.-the poverty of their backgrounds?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Yes of course but one soon learns that teaching is crowd control - we’re a branch of the social services. Barbara spots a boy stealing a Kit Kat.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (To boy) Put it back! Sheba looks mournful, Sue tries to rally her.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Console yourself with the gems. Every now and then you find one with an agile mind and a will to learn. That’s when it’s satisfying, when you can really make a difference. Sheba seems to really ‘hear’ this.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: The rest is just cattle prod and pray. They carry their trays to a vacant table. Barbara watches Sheba intently, she seems so defeated by it all. But her sadness is beautiful to behold... [a

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I can see why others are beguiled by her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara waiting outside.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But I wonder if she possesses the requisite heft? Sheba emerges pulling on her coat, surprised to see Barba there.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Fancy a coffee?

dialogues.speaker: SHEBA
dialogues.text: Mmm. They head off. But then Barbara spots SUE emerging from t other side of the playground. She tries to usher Sheba at speed but Sue is gaining on them. A chase! Fatally, Barbara glances back and Sheba follows suit. she sees the panting Sue and waits for her to join them - muc Barbara’s frustration. INT. GREASY CAFF — LATER Barbara smoking - ever so slightly sulking. Sue and Sheba cappuccinos. Sue mock taps the table with her spoon.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Ahem. I’ve got a bit of an announcement:

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You’re leaving St George’s?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (flatly) oh, you’re pregnant. Sue registers a moment of anti-climactic sadness.

dialogues.speaker: SHEBA
dialogues.text: That’s fantastic! Congratulations! When are you due?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: June the seventh.

dialogues.speaker: SHEBA
dialogues.text: A summer baby, how lovely.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: So you'll be taking maternity leave?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Mmm, can’t wait! Barbara nods, encouragingly.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Rest is so important.

dialogues.speaker: SHEBA
dialogues.text: Do you know what it is? Sheba catches Barbara’s eye and suggests she put her cigarette out. Barbara does so but only to please her.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Rog reckons it’s a boy but I'm certain it’s a girl. Aren’t they supposed to be iow slung? I can’t believe nobody noticed, I’m 14 weeks! Didn’t you see how chunky I’m getting?! Barbara notices a dab of froth on Sheba’s nose. She hands a serviette. Sheba thanks her with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara and Sheba waiting outside. Sue inside buying a ho water bottle.

dialogues.speaker: SHEBA
dialogues.text: Do you want to come for lunch, on Sunday?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: SHEBA
dialogues.text: To mine, to our house.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Won't you be with your family?

dialogues.speaker: SHEBA
dialogues.text: Yes but you’re very welcome. It’s no big deal, I’1l just do a lasagne or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I adore lasagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara is almost blushing.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Bliss! Women's wear. A SHOP ASSISTANT nods as Barbara discusses virtues of a skirt she’s interested in.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A merry flag on the Arctic wilderness of my calendar. Shoe Department. Five different pairs for consideration. To ANOTHER SHOP ASSISTANT’s relief Barbara finally plumps a pair of black, low heelers with a strap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara seemingly asleep while the GIRL washes her hair.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: One must make an effort when one receives an invitation. She half opens one eye and sees the girl making faces. Th gixl at the next sink mocks her own customer similarly. INT. BARBARA’S FLAT - EVENING Barbara walks into the bedroom in her new heels. She twir in front of the mirror, ‘catching herself’.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The art of it is seeming not to. Barbara carefully spray starches her white blouse. INT/EXT. BARBARA’S CAR/STREET - SUNDAY Barbara cruising down the street looking for a space. Her Polo incongrucus amongst the smart cars already parked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lasagne tends to disagree with my bowels... She parks and takes out her compact, touches up her make She’s early. And nervous.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: T’1l ask for a small portion. She lights a cigarette. Determined to stay calm. EXT. SHEBA’S HOUSE ~- TEN MINUTES LATER Barbara walks up the front steps of a large Victorian hou She observes the front garden; a cherry tree, a rusty bik mildewed cricket bat handle impaled in the unkempt grass. She stands there, pristine in her grey skirt, white blous new black heels. She holds a bunch of flowers. She composes herself and presses the bell. No sound. She tries again. Waits. Nothing. She tries the knocker. The door is opened by a tall, slightly shaggy MAN in his fifties.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: I think I’ve come to the wrong house.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (smiles) . No, you're bang on. I’m Richard. Come in!

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, I thought—

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That I’‘d be twenty years younger and twice as handsome. He helps her out of her coat.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Sorry, were you out there long? The bell’s knackered. /lo He dumps her coat over the bannister. The hall is clutte with junk, boots, bicycles etc.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Bash! A flustered Sheba pokes her head out the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: SHEBA
dialogues.text: Hi, Barbara! The kitchen’s on fire! Richard raises an eyebrow and ushers Barbara: INT. SITTING ROOM — CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Oh, what a splendid room.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What can I get you? We’re semi-pro drinkers here; absinthe, hooch, pick your poison.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Could I have a dry sherry, please?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Erm...I might have some apricot brandy knocking around...

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Or a dry white wine?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Done. Have a seat. Barbara takes in the room; the look is ‘battered bourgeoi the big sofas, the bare boards, paintings, overflowing bookshelves, Sunday papers. She sits in an armchair and finds herself semi-recumbent is its hidden depth. A GIRL of 15 drifts in. She quietly observes as Barbara struggles to sit up.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You must be Polly.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Must be. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: I’m Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Barbara. Polly’s contempt is instantaneous but she makes a vague s at concealing it. She flops into a sofa, sips her bottle of Evian.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: Are you going somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: You’re all poshed up.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Oh...I have an appointment. Later. In town. (beat) Have you always lived here?

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: Mum inherited it. It’s her little joke -

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (coming in) - I only married her for the property. He carries an opened bottle of wine and glasses.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (To Polly) Morning. He hands drinks round.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Did Pete go? Polly nods.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: He was welcome to stay.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: He’s not really into lunch.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (To Barbara) cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: A witless Chardonnay.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Are you interested in wine?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Only the drinking part. You?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Well, I spent a portion of the summer on the Amalfi coast and I became- She's interrupted by loud thumps as someone thunders down wooden stairs.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Here’s trouble... BEN runs in and leaps head first onto the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Easy, Rocky! Easy! Ben is twelve. He has Down’s Syndrome. Barbara didn’t kno She watches Richard and his son playfully fighting with e other.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'd anticipated a suave, young lawyer and two perfect poppets. Not so. She's married some crumbling patriarch - he’s nearly as old as me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone sat at the big table, eating their slightly burn lasagne and salad- Barbara has a tiny portion, almost untouched. She conceal with a large lettuce leaf.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And then there’s the daughter; a pocket princess. Polly picks at her food, uninterested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And finally, a somewhat tiresome court jester. Ben wolfs his food down, makin hi s i habitually. 1 g a mess which Sheba wipes up

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I’m going to be a wizard.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Oh? ...Is that when you‘re a growh up...?

dialogues.speaker: SHEBA
dialogues.text: No, he’s just been cast in his school play! Ben beams with pride as Sheba hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (critic’s voice) Amongst next year’s cultural highlights I greatly look forward to Benjamin Hart in the key role of ‘The Wizard’. Indeed I find myself to be beside myself with anticipation for this doubtless auspicious stage debut. As Richard continues...

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A rogue image swam through me, hubby’s pruney old mouth pursed at Sheba’s breast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheba and Ben are dancing to ‘Funky Kingston’ by Toots an the Maytals up loud on the Bang & Olufsen.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After lunch a rather mortifying family tradition... Sheba’s quite drunk and having a ball. Richard moves to h own slower rhythm amusing the delighted Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They do things differently in bourgeois bohemia. Polly and Barbara, sour bedfellows on the sofa, both mort embarrassed. Polly offers Barbara a fag which she accepts gratefully. 0  As the music continues Barbara's expression changes: her admiration for Sheba’s enthusiasm, her love for her son, natural warmth, her beauty... dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (softly) I need more than a friend. They look at each other. No anger, just stalemate. Sheba hands Barbara the journal and leaves. Barbara in her trashed flat. Desolate. She places the journal on an empty shelf.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TAXI/LONDON STREETS
dialogues.text: Sheba in a cab, heading home. EXT. SHEBA’S HOUSE - NIGHT Sheba stood outside her house. Warm lights on inside. She climbs the stairs and nervously knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a while Richard opens it. They look at each other. And then he motions her in and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bustle of people. Barbara amongst then. INT. STATIONERS. Barbara selects a new journal from the shelf. She goes to the checkout - ignoring the section where the sell the gold stars. EXT. BARBARA'S STREET. Barbara walking, her new journal in its plastic bag. She heads down the concrete stairs to her front door. INT. BARBARA’S FLAT, SITTING ROOM - DAY Barbara at. her kitchen table. The flat looks bare and bl stripped of all life. She takes out her new diary and smooths down the spine on first page. She uncaps her pen, poised to write. ‘ She thinks. Nothing to say. She sits in silence. ‘

dialogues.speaker: EXT, PARLIAMENT HILL
dialogues.text: CLOSE: newspaper headline: ‘Sex Teacher sentenced to 16 months’ - Under it a press photo of Sheba being shepherded into cou by Richard. A WOMAN sat on ‘the’ bench reading the newspaper. She sip takeaway cappuccino, reads on, engrossed in the story.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (0-S.)
dialogues.text: I knew her...  [So The woman turns, Barbara is standing behind her.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: We taught at the same school.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: God. What was she like?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (thinks) ---A bit chilly. And perhaps a touch...furtive. A sort of absent person. But I didn’t know her well. (beat) May I? She sits next to the woman.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Do you still teach?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: No, no, retired. Thank goodness. The woman sips her coffee producing a little dab of froth her nose. Barbara points to it, amused. The woman shrugs, charmingly, and searches for a tissue. In an instant Barb produces one and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Thanks. They sit back admiring the view.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: I do love it here.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Mmm.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: It’s spectacular at dusk. Barbara turns to her lovely new prey.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: I’m Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Annabel.  They shake hands. As they continue to talk the camera moves behind them to in the view, as at the beginning. Two women on a bench. The city in the distance. FADE TO BLACK. Joy
